description: The NBA suspended the season on March 11 after Rudy Gobert of the Utah Jazz tested positive for the coronavirus. Thirteen teams from the Western Conference and nine from the East will travel to the Walt Disney World resort in Orlando, Florida, on July 7, according to Shams Charania of The Athletic. “While we are disappointed that the announced return to play...
text:
The Cavaliers expressed disappointment over the end of their season and their
unrequited desire to be part of the NBA's restart plan, which was approved by
the league's Board of Governors on Thursday.

The Cavs issued a statement even before the NBA Players Association signed off
on the 22-team format, expected in a conference call scheduled for Friday,
according to ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski.

The Cavs (19-46), last in the Eastern Conference, were among eight teams left
out in the plan announced by the league to resume play on July 31. The NBA
suspended the season on March 11 after Rudy Gobert of the Utah Jazz tested
positive for the coronavirus.

Thirteen teams from the Western Conference and nine from the East will travel
to the Walt Disney World resort in Orlando, Florida, on July 7, according to
Shams Charania of The Athletic. Eight "seeding games" will be held to
determine the playoff field.

"While we are disappointed that the announced return to play proposal excludes
the Cleveland Cavaliers, we understand all of the unprecedented factors that
contributed to this outcome and we accept the hard decisions Commissioner Adam
Silver and the NBA's Board of Governors had to make," Cavs General Manager
Koby Altman and coach J.B. Bickerstaff said in a joint statement. "We also
respect the exhaustive and life-altering measures that were considered as a
result of COVID-19, but as a team, we greatly desired to be a part of the
season's resumption.

"We were hopeful to be granted the opportunity to continue the 2019-20 season
and join our counterparts in Orlando to further the development of our young
team in meaningful basketball games, and also feed off the positive momentum
we had built prior to the league shutdown on March 11. Collectively, our
players want to compete at the highest level and we will unquestionably use
this as added motivation as we continue working towards a sustainable culture
of winning."

The Cavs went 5-6 after Bickerstaff was promoted from associate head coach
after John Beilein and the team parted ways on Feb. 19.

All five victories came against teams invited to Orlando. That list includes
the Denver Nuggets (third in the West), Miami Heat (fourth in the East),
Philadelphia 76ers (sixth in the East), San Antonio Spurs (four games out of
the West's eight seed) and Washington Wizards (5½ games out of eighth place in
the East).

The NBA said if the July 31 restart is not disrupted by the pandemic, the
draft lottery would be held on Aug. 25 and the NBA Draft on Oct. 15, three
days after a possible Game 7 of The Finals.

The league said the eight teams not returning to play and the six teams
participating in the restart that do not qualify for the playoffs will be
seeded in the lottery by their records on March 11. The 16 playoff teams will
go in inverse order of their combined records in regular-season games and the
seeding games in Orlando.

The Cavs can select no lower than sixth in the draft and have a 14 percent
chance of getting the No. 1 pick in the lottery.

The league said the 2020-21 regular season would likely begin on Dec. 1, with
Charania reporting that training camp would start on Nov. 10. That would mean
the Cavs will go nearly nine months between games.

"Although the time away from our incredible fanbase in Cleveland and across
Northeast Ohio is unfortunate, we look forward to finding ways to continue
utilizing our platform and available resources to reach out in our community
to help affect change and take sustainable action in the fight against racial
injustice," Altman and Bickerstaff said, in reference to the May 25 death of
George Floyd and the ensuing protests to end racism.

The Cavs also released an organizational statement that praised how the
"players, coaches and entire organization has faced this incredibly
challenging time."

"So much of what we've learned about our team and ourselves as an organization
during this journey, though, has nothing to do with basketball and everything
to do with love, character, community and our culture," it said. "All of which
are things we will continue to amplify."

According to multiple reports, the Portland Trail Blazers were the lone
dissenter in the Board of Governors' vote.

CREDIT: MARLA RIDENOUR

title: Cavs’ season officially over
html:
The Cavaliers expressed disappointment over the end of their season and their unrequited desire to be part of the NBA’s restart plan, which was approved by the league’s Board of Governors on Thursday.

The Cavs issued a statement even before the NBA Players Association signed off on the 22-team format, expected in a conference call scheduled for Friday, according to ESPN’s Adrian Wojnarowski.

The Cavs (19-46), last in the Eastern Conference, were among eight teams left out in the plan announced by the league to resume play on July 31. The NBA suspended the season on March 11 after Rudy Gobert of the Utah Jazz tested positive for the coronavirus.

Thirteen teams from the Western Conference and nine from the East will travel to the Walt Disney World resort in Orlando, Florida, on July 7, according to Shams Charania of The Athletic. Eight “seeding games” will be held to determine the playoff field.

“While we are disappointed that the announced return to play proposal excludes the Cleveland Cavaliers, we understand all of the unprecedented factors that contributed to this outcome and we accept the hard decisions Commissioner Adam Silver and the NBA’s Board of Governors had to make,” Cavs General Manager Koby Altman and coach J.B. Bickerstaff said in a joint statement. “We also respect the exhaustive and life-altering measures that were considered as a result of COVID-19, but as a team, we greatly desired to be a part of the season’s resumption.

“We were hopeful to be granted the opportunity to continue the 2019-20 season and join our counterparts in Orlando to further the development of our young team in meaningful basketball games, and also feed off the positive momentum we had built prior to the league shutdown on March 11. Collectively, our players want to compete at the highest level and we will unquestionably use this as added motivation as we continue working towards a sustainable culture of winning.”

The Cavs went 5-6 after Bickerstaff was promoted from associate head coach after John Beilein and the team parted ways on Feb. 19.

All five victories came against teams invited to Orlando. That list includes the Denver Nuggets (third in the West), Miami Heat (fourth in the East), Philadelphia 76ers (sixth in the East), San Antonio Spurs (four games out of the West’s eight seed) and Washington Wizards (5½ games out of eighth place in the East).

The NBA said if the July 31 restart is not disrupted by the pandemic, the draft lottery would be held on Aug. 25 and the NBA Draft on Oct. 15, three days after a possible Game 7 of The Finals.

The league said the eight teams not returning to play and the six teams participating in the restart that do not qualify for the playoffs will be seeded in the lottery by their records on March 11. The 16 playoff teams will go in inverse order of their combined records in regular-season games and the seeding games in Orlando.

The Cavs can select no lower than sixth in the draft and have a 14 percent chance of getting the No. 1 pick in the lottery.

The league said the 2020-21 regular season would likely begin on Dec. 1, with Charania reporting that training camp would start on Nov. 10. That would mean the Cavs will go nearly nine months between games.

“Although the time away from our incredible fanbase in Cleveland and across Northeast Ohio is unfortunate, we look forward to finding ways to continue utilizing our platform and available resources to reach out in our community to help affect change and take sustainable action in the fight against racial injustice,” Altman and Bickerstaff said, in reference to the May 25 death of George Floyd and the ensuing protests to end racism.

The Cavs also released an organizational statement that praised how the “players, coaches and entire organization has faced this incredibly challenging time.”

“So much of what we’ve learned about our team and ourselves as an organization during this journey, though, has nothing to do with basketball and everything to do with love, character, community and our culture,” it said. “All of which are things we will continue to amplify.”

According to multiple reports, the Portland Trail Blazers were the lone dissenter in the Board of Governors’ vote.

CREDIT: MARLA RIDENOUR
